 she "has fought very hard" and urges British parliament to vote yes.

After five days I now feel generally on top of the draft withdrawal agreement.

Anyone who has managed to get on top of the text in less time has my admiration.

And those politicians who mastered it in a few hours before drafting resignations or deciding to vote against, my awe.

html: I'm very pro EU (not just anti this mess) and still not convinced of merits of another referendum. A referendum got us into this mess. Another won't clean it up. The issue is the political temperature is too high and we need something to bring country together. Leadership needed
text:
I'm very pro EU (not just anti this mess) and still not convinced of merits of another referendum. A referendum got us into this mess. Another won't clean it up.

The issue is the political temperature is too high and we need something to bring country together. Leadership needed

html: Bit of clarity needed - being against this deal implies support for one of: 1. No deal 2. No Brexit 3. Canada + with NI only backstop So opponents of the deal should be clear which one they support. There is no other magic option.
text:
Bit of clarity needed - being against this deal implies support for one of:

1. No deal
2. No Brexit
3. Canada + with NI only backstop

So opponents of the deal should be clear which one they support.

There is no other magic option.

May has come back with inferior deal but it’s* better than no deal (for which we are not prepared), better than Remaining and better than a second referendum which would only open new wounds. It’s why, reluctantly, I’d vote for it if I were an MP.

* Assuming no nasties in text.

text:

html: This will be familiar to many, but I love the fact that Bluetooth technology owes its name to a 10th century ruler - one King Harald Bluetooth, who united Denmark and Norway. His nickname was thought appropriate for technology that brings devices together.

html: Some positive news for UK science & research in the #Budget2018: £1.6bn more to strengthen UK science & R&D Aim to build world’s first quantum computer & new fusion power plant £100m PhD training & £50m for AI fellowships £115m to help businesses access cutting-edge tech
text:
Some positive news for UK science & research in the #Budget2018:
£1.6bn more to strengthen UK science & R&D
Aim to build world’s first quantum computer & new fusion power plant
£100m PhD training & £50m for AI fellowships
£115m to help businesses access cutting-edge tech

text:
Brexiter trade policy:
1. We don't need a trade deal with our biggest market, WTO terms are fine.
2. We must have trade deals with our smaller markets, WTO terms aren't good enough
3. We must leave EU trade deals & try to roll them over on same terms because, er ... somethinghttps://twitter.com/nickeardleybbc/status/1050737192308498432 …

html: In 2005, I wrote about what it was like growing up around the estates of Ladbroke Grove because it felt like nobody was writing about lives like mine. Now my words are being used to attack me.
